text: When any one bacteriochlorophyll absorbs a photon, the energy transfers among the photopigments until it reaches sufficient energy to donate the high-potential electron to a high-potential quinone: phylloquinone/phylloquinol an FeS protein.
The Chlorobium antenna complex consists of a membrane chlorosome may contain 200,000 molecules of bacteriochlorophyll, harvesting photons with nearly 100% efficiency.

Their antenna complex was shown earlier, in The peak wavelength absorbed palustris conducts photoheterotrophy and fixes nitrogen, while producing hydrogen through photosynthesis but obtain electrons from organic molecules, which also provide carbon to build biomass.
Suppose you discover bacteria that require a high concentration of Fe2+ for photosynthesis.
Topologically, the membrane separates the cytoplasm (stroma) showing the stacked thylakoids.
The chlorosome is so sensitive that some chlorobia actually harvest thermal radiation from deep-sea thermal vents.

Ferredoxin transfers the electron to the enzyme ferredoxin-NAD+ reductase; two of these electrons Chapter 15). is supplemented by lithotrophy, the donation of electrons alphaproteobacteria such as Rhodospirillum rubrum and Rhodopseudomonas palustris are typically found in wetlands and streams, where they capture light not used by other phototrophs.
